original_title: Sri Lanka university lecturers to meet president on IMF-prescribed tax hike
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – University lecturers in Sri Lanka who have been up in arms over an International Monetary Fund (IMF)-backed tax hike has been invited to a meeting with President Ranil Wickremesinghe to discuss their grievances.

Media spokesman of the Federation of University Teachers Association (FUTA) Charudaththa Illangasinghe told reporters on Thursday May 18 that FUTA representatives plan to explain matters to the president at the meeting scheduled to be held later that day.
“The government has so far not been sensitive to this issue. The president has given a meeting to FUTA. We wish to explain to him the problems that he has yet to identify.

“We hope he becomes sensitive to the crisis that the education sector and this country’s future could be facing and take a clear and acceptable decision. If not ,there is a danger of education collapsing,” said Illangasinghe.

A meeting between the president and the university lecturers who have been agitating against the tax reforms has been on the cards since March. A meeting was held with President’s Secretary Saman Ekanayake on March 17.

FUTA and other trade unions as well as professional associations across different sectors have been engaging in trade union action that included strikes at various points since the introduction of the tax increase.

High-income earning public servants in higher education, medical, banking, ports and other sectors have been resisting the IMF-backed progressive income tax hike that saw the cash-strapped government collect from anyone earning over 100,000 rupees a month.
A team of senior IMF officials who are in Sri Lanka on a mission ahead of a review of the country’s 17th IMF programme met a number of trade unions to discuss the issue.

IMF Asia and Pacific Department Director Krishna Srinivasan, who was in the delegation, said there was broad recognition among the various stakeholder groups he met that Sri Lanka has been through a crisis and ambitious reforms are necessary despite some differences of opinion.

“There are differences of views in terms of reform priorities, the pace of reforms, and so on. But there is a broader recognition that the country was in crisis and that ambitious reforms are needed ,and that they should be pursued in a comprehensive way,” said Srinivasan.
“You’ll have various stakeholders and they’ll have different views. That’s to be expected,” he added.
